Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Every year, about 1,000 new words are
added to the Oxford English Dictionary. Where do they come from, and how do they make it 
into our everyday lives? With over 170,000 words currently in use
in the English language, it might seem we already have plenty. Yet, as our world changes, new ideas and inventions spring forth, and science progresses, our existing words leave gaps
in what we want to express and we fill those gaps 
in several ingenious, practical, and occasionally peculiar ways. One way is to absorb a word
from another language. English has borrowed so many words
over its history that nearly half of its vocabulary 
comes directly from other languages. Sometimes, this is simply because
the thing the word describes was borrowed itself. Rome and France brought legal
and religious concepts, like altar and jury, to Medieval England, while trade brought crops and cuisine, like Arabic coffee, Italian spaghetti, and Indian curry. But sometimes, another language 
has just the right word for a complex idea or emotion, like naïveté machismo, or schadenfreude. Scientists also use classical languages
to name new concepts. Clone, for example, was derived from
the Ancient Greek word for twig to describe creating a new plant
from a piece of the old. And today, the process works both ways, with English lending words like software
to languages all over the world. Another popular way 
to fill a vocabulary gap is by combining existing words that each
convey part of the new concept. This can be done by combining two
whole words into a compound word, like airport or starfish, or by clipping and blending parts of words
together, like spork, brunch, or internet. And unlike borrowings 
from other languages, these can often be understood
the first time you hear them. And sometimes a new word isn't new at all. Obsolete words gain new life by adopting
new meanings. Villain originally meant a peasant farmer,
but in a twist of aristocratic snobbery came to mean someone not bound
by the knightly code of chivalry and, therefore, a bad person. A geek went from 
being a carnival performer to any strange person to a specific type of awkward genius. And other times, words come to mean
their opposite through irony, metaphor, or misuse, like when sick or wicked are used
to describe something literally amazing. But if words can be formed 
in all these ways, why do some become mainstream
while others fall out of use or never catch on in the first place? Sometimes, the answer is simple, as when scientists or companies 
give an official name to a new discovery or technology. And some countries have language academies
to make the decisions. But for the most part, official sources
like dictionaries only document current usage. New words don't originate from above,
but from ordinary people spreading words that 
hit the right combination of useful and catchy. Take the word meme, coined in the 1970s 
by sociobiologist Richard Dawkins from the Ancient Greek for imitation. He used it to describe how ideas
and symbols propagate through a culture like genes through a population. With the advent of the Internet, the process became directly observable
in how jokes and images were popularized at lightning speed. And soon, the word came to refer
to a certain kind of image. So meme not only describes how words
become part of language, the word is a meme itself. And there's a word for this phenomenon
of words that describe themselves: autological. Not all new words are created equal. Some stick around for millennia, some adapt to changing times, and others die off. Some relay information, some interpret it, but the way these words are created and the journey they take to become
part of our speech tells us a lot about our world
and how we communicate within it.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: One way a word enters a language is by:
Options: A. Borrowing it from another language, B. Cloning an existing word, C. Luck, D. Eliminating another word
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: How many new words are added to the Oxford English Dictionary every year? Options: A. 100, B. 1,000, C. 10,000, D. 100,000 Correct Option: None
Question 2: What percentage of the English language vocabulary comes directly from other languages? Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 50%, D. 70% Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the origin of the word "clone"? Options: A. Derived from the Ancient Greek word for "copy", B. Derived from the Ancient Greek word for "twig", C. Derived from the Latin word for "plant", D. Derived from the French word for "cell" Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is an example of a compound word? Options: A. Software, B. Airport, C. Internet, D. Brunch Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the original meaning of the word "villain"? Options: A. A bad person, B. A peasant farmer, C. A knight, D. A lord Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the term for words that describe themselves? Options: A. Autological, B. Etymological, C. Lexical, D. Semantic Correct Option: None
Question 7: Who coined the word "meme" in the 1970s? Options: A. Richard Dawkins, B. Charles Darwin, C. Stephen Hawking, D. Isaac Newton Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the origin of the word "meme"? Options: A. Derived from the Ancient Greek word for "idea", B. Derived from the Ancient Greek word for "imitation", C. Derived from the Latin word for "image", D. Derived from the French word for "joke" Correct Option: None
Question 9: How do new words typically become part of the language? Options: A. Through official sources like dictionaries, B. Through language academies, C. Through ordinary people spreading words that hit the right combination of useful and catchy, D. Through scientific discoveries Correct Option: None
Question 10: What happens to some words over time? Options: A. They remain unchanged, B. They adapt to changing times, C. They die off, D. All of the above Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 9: How do new words typically become part of the language? Options: A. Through official sources like dictionaries, B. Through language academies, C. Through ordinary people spreading words that hit the right combination of useful and catchy, D. Through scientific discoveries.

However, this question does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ. A more suitable match would be a generated MCQ that explicitly mentions "borrowing from another language" as an option.

Since there isn't a perfect match among the provided generated MCQs, I will choose the one that is closest in terms of content and intent. 

A suitable alternative is Question 2: What percentage of the English language vocabulary comes directly from other languages? Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 50%, D. 70%. This question implies that the English language borrows words from other languages, which is the core idea of the ground truth MCQ.

However, an even better match would be Question 3, if its content were more focused on the concept of borrowing words.

Considering the transcript's content about the English language borrowing words from other languages, I would re-evaluate the options.

The best match among the provided generated MCQs would be the one that can be linked to the idea of borrowing words from other languages.

The correct index of the most similar generated MCQ is: 2

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Every year, about 1,000 new words are
added to the Oxford English Dictionary. Where do they come from, and how do they make it 
into our everyday lives? With over 170,000 words currently in use
in the English language, it might seem we already have plenty. Yet, as our world changes, new ideas and inventions spring forth, and science progresses, our existing words leave gaps
in what we want to express and we fill those gaps 
in several ingenious, practical, and occasionally peculiar ways. One way is to absorb a word
from another language. English has borrowed so many words
over its history that nearly half of its vocabulary 
comes directly from other languages. Sometimes, this is simply because
the thing the word describes was borrowed itself. Rome and France brought legal
and religious concepts, like altar and jury, to Medieval England, while trade brought crops and cuisine, like Arabic coffee, Italian spaghetti, and Indian curry. But sometimes, another language 
has just the right word for a complex idea or emotion, like naïveté machismo, or schadenfreude. Scientists also use classical languages

the Ancient Greek word for twig to describe creating a new plant
from a piece of the old. And today, the process works both ways, with English lending words like software
to languages all over the world. Another popular way 
to fill a vocabulary gap is by combining existing words that each

the first time you hear them. And sometimes a new word isn't new at all. Obsolete words gain new life by adopting
new meanings. Villain originally meant a peasant farmer,
but in a twist of aristocratic snobbery came to mean someone not bound
by the knightly code of chivalry and, therefore, a bad person. A geek went from 
being a carnival performer to any strange person to a specific type of awkward genius. And other times, words come to mean
their opposite through irony, metaphor, or misuse, like when sick or wicked are used
to describe something literally amazing. But if words can be formed 
in all these ways, why do some become mainstream
while others fall out of use or never catch on in the first place? Sometimes, the answer is simple, as when scientists or companies 
give an official name to a new discovery or technology. And some countries have language academies
to make the decisions. But for the most part, official sources
like dictionaries only document current usage. New words don't originate from above,
but from ordinary people spreading words that 
hit the right combination of useful and catchy. Take the word meme, coined in the 1970s 
by sociobiologist Richard Dawkins from the Ancient Greek for imitation. He used it to describe how ideas
and symbols propagate through a culture like genes through a population. With the advent of the Internet, the process became directly observable
in how jokes and images were popularized at lightning speed. And soon, the word came to refer
to a certain kind of image. So meme not only describes how words
become part of language, the word is a meme itself. And there's a word for this phenomenon
of words that describe themselves: autological. Not all new words are created equal. Some stick around for millennia, some adapt to changing times, and others die off. Some relay information, some interpret it, but the way these words are created and the journey they take to become
part of our speech tells us a lot about our world
and how we communicate within it.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Scientists sometimes use ______ to name a new idea.
Options: A. An already-existing term, B. A synonym, C. Words from a classical language, D. Random phonetic sounds
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: How many new words are added to the Oxford English Dictionary every year? Options: A. 100, B. 1,000, C. 10,000, D. 100,000 Correct Option: None
Question 2: What percentage of the English language vocabulary comes directly from other languages? Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 50%, D. 70% Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the origin of the word "clone"? Options: A. Derived from the Ancient Greek word for "copy", B. Derived from the Ancient Greek word for "twig", C. Derived from the Latin word for "plant", D. Derived from the French word for "cell" Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is an example of a compound word? Options: A. Software, B. Airport, C. Internet, D. Brunch Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the original meaning of the word "villain"? Options: A. A bad person, B. A peasant farmer, C. A knight, D. A lord Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the term for words that describe themselves? Options: A. Autological, B. Etymological, C. Lexical, D. Semantic Correct Option: None
Question 7: Who coined the word "meme" in the 1970s? Options: A. Richard Dawkins, B. Charles Darwin, C. Stephen Hawking, D. Isaac Newton Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the origin of the word "meme"? Options: A. Derived from the Ancient Greek word for "idea", B. Derived from the Ancient Greek word for "imitation", C. Derived from the Latin word for "image", D. Derived from the French word for "joke" Correct Option: None
Question 9: How do new words typically become part of the language? Options: A. Through official sources like dictionaries, B. Through language academies, C. Through ordinary people spreading words that hit the right combination of useful and catchy, D. Through scientific discoveries Correct Option: None
Question 10: What happens to some words over time? Options: A. They remain unchanged, B. They adapt to changing times, C. They die off, D. All of the above Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3: What is the origin of the word "clone"? 

Although the question is not an exact match, the content and options of Question 3 are related to the ground truth MCQ, which asks about scientists using classical languages to name new ideas. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Every year, about 1,000 new words are
added to the Oxford English Dictionary. Where do they come from, and how do they make it 
into our everyday lives? With over 170,000 words currently in use
in the English language, it might seem we already have plenty. Yet, as our world changes, new ideas and inventions spring forth, and science progresses, our existing words leave gaps
in what we want to express and we fill those gaps 
in several ingenious, practical, and occasionally peculiar ways. One way is to absorb a word
from another language. English has borrowed so many words
over its history that nearly half of its vocabulary 
comes directly from other languages. Sometimes, this is simply because
the thing the word describes was borrowed itself. Rome and France brought legal
and religious concepts, like altar and jury, to Medieval England, while trade brought crops and cuisine, like Arabic coffee, Italian spaghetti, and Indian curry. But sometimes, another language 
has just the right word for a complex idea or emotion, like naïveté machismo, or schadenfreude. Scientists also use classical languages
to name new concepts. Clone, for example, was derived from
the Ancient Greek word for twig to describe creating a new plant
from a piece of the old. And today, the process works both ways, with English lending words like software
to languages all over the world. Another popular way 
to fill a vocabulary gap is by combining existing words that each
convey part of the new concept. This can be done by combining two
whole words into a compound word, like airport or starfish, or by clipping and blending parts of words
together, like spork, brunch, or internet. And unlike borrowings 
from other languages, these can often be understood
the first time you hear them. And sometimes a new word isn't new at all. Obsolete words gain new life by adopting
new meanings. Villain originally meant a peasant farmer,
but in a twist of aristocratic snobbery came to mean someone not bound
by the knightly code of chivalry and, therefore, a bad person. A geek went from 
being a carnival performer to any strange person to a specific type of awkward genius. And other times, words come to mean
their opposite through irony, metaphor, or misuse, like when sick or wicked are used
to describe something literally amazing. But if words can be formed 
in all these ways, why do some become mainstream
while others fall out of use or never catch on in the first place? Sometimes, the answer is simple, as when scientists or companies 
give an official name to a new discovery or technology. And some countries have language academies
to make the decisions. But for the most part, official sources
like dictionaries only document current usage. New words don't originate from above,
but from ordinary people spreading words that 
hit the right combination of useful and catchy. Take the word meme, coined in the 1970s 
by sociobiologist Richard Dawkins from the Ancient Greek for imitation. He used it to describe how ideas
and symbols propagate through a culture like genes through a population. With the advent of the Internet, the process became directly observable
in how jokes and images were popularized at lightning speed. And soon, the word came to refer
to a certain kind of image. So meme not only describes how words
become part of language, the word is a meme itself. And there's a word for this phenomenon
of words that describe themselves: autological. Not all new words are created equal. Some stick around for millennia, some adapt to changing times, and others die off. Some relay information, some interpret it, but the way these words are created and the journey they take to become
part of our speech tells us a lot about our world
and how we communicate within it.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A way to fill-in a conceptual gap in a language is to:
Options: A. Ignore it, B. Combine existing words, C. Look up a new word, D. Guess
Correct Option: B

Question 3: What is the origin of the word "clone"? Options: A. Derived from the Ancient Greek word for "copy", B. Derived from the Ancient Greek word for "twig", C. Derived from the Latin word for "plant", D. Derived from the French word for "cell" Correct Option: None

Through ordinary people spreading words that hit the right combination of useful and catchy, D. Through scientific discoveries Correct Option: None

**Transcript**:
Every year, about 1,000 new words are
added to the Oxford English Dictionary. Where do they come from, and how do they make it 
into our everyday lives? With over 170,000 words currently in use
in the English language, it might seem we already have plenty. Yet, as our world changes, new ideas and inventions spring forth, and science progresses, our existing words leave gaps
in what we want to express and we fill those gaps 
in several ingenious, practical, and occasionally peculiar ways. One way is to absorb a word
from another language. English has borrowed so many words
over its history that nearly half of its vocabulary 
comes directly from other languages. Sometimes, this is simply because
the thing the word describes was borrowed itself. Rome and France brought legal
and religious concepts, like altar and jury, to Medieval England, while trade brought crops and cuisine, like Arabic coffee, Italian spaghetti, and Indian curry. But sometimes, another language 
has just the right word for a complex idea or emotion, like naïveté machismo, or schadenfreude. Scientists also use classical languages
to name new concepts. Clone, for example, was derived from
the Ancient Greek word for twig to describe creating a new plant
from a piece of the old. And today, the process works both ways, with English lending words like software
to languages all over the world. Another popular way 
to fill a vocabulary gap is by combining existing words that each
convey part of the new concept. This can be done by combining two
whole words into a compound word, like airport or starfish, or by clipping and blending parts of words
together, like spork, brunch, or internet. And unlike borrowings 
from other languages, these can often be understood
the first time you hear them. And sometimes a new word isn't new at all. Obsolete words gain new life by adopting
new meanings. Villain originally meant a peasant farmer,
but in a twist of aristocratic snobbery came to mean someone not bound
by the knightly code of chivalry and, therefore, a bad person. A geek went from 
being a carnival performer to any strange person to a specific type of awkward genius. And other times, words come to mean
their opposite through irony, metaphor, or misuse, like when sick or wicked are used
to describe something literally amazing. But if words can be formed 
in all these ways, why do some become mainstream
while others fall out of use or never catch on in the first place? Sometimes, the answer is simple, as when scientists or companies 
give an official name to a new discovery or technology. And some countries have language academies
to make the decisions. But for the most part, official sources
like dictionaries only document current usage. New words don't originate from above,
but from ordinary people spreading words that 
hit the right combination of useful and catchy. Take the word meme, coined in the 1970s 
by sociobiologist Richard Dawkins from the Ancient Greek for imitation. He used it to describe how ideas
and symbols propagate through a culture like genes through a population. With the advent of the Internet, the process became directly observable
in how jokes and images were popularized at lightning speed. And soon, the word came to refer
to a certain kind of image. So meme not only describes how words
become part of language, the word is a meme itself. And there's a word for this phenomenon
of words that describe themselves: autological. Not all new words are created equal. Some stick around for millennia, some adapt to changing times, and others die off. Some relay information, some interpret it, but the way these words are created and the journey they take to become
part of our speech tells us a lot about our world
and how we communicate within it.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The word meme came about through:
Options: A. Analogy with the word gene, B. Borrowing from another language, C. A dictionary look-up process, D. Speculation
Correct Option: A

into our everyday lives? With over 170,000 words currently in use
in the English language, it might seem we already have plenty. Yet, as our world changes, new ideas and inventions spring forth, and science progresses, our existing words leave gaps
in what we want to express and we fill those gaps 
in several ingenious, practical, and occasionally peculiar ways. One way is to absorb a word

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Consider the classic white t-shirt. Annually, we sell and buy
two billion t-shirts globally, making it one of the most common
garments in the world. But how and where is the average
t-shirt made, and what's its environmental impact? Clothing items can vary a lot, but a typical t-shirt begins its life
on a farm in America, China, or India where cotton seeds are sown, irrigated and
grown for the fluffy bolls they produce. Self-driving machines carefully harvest
these puffs, an industrial cotton gin mechanically
separates the fluffy bolls from the seeds, and the cotton lint is pressed 
into 225-kilogram bales. The cotton plants require a huge quantity
of water and pesticides. 2,700 liters of water are needed to produce
the average t-shirt, enough to fill more than 30 bathtubs. Meanwhile, cotton uses more insecticides
and pesticides than any other crop in the world. These pollutants can be carcinogenic, harm the health of field workers, and damage surrounding ecosystems. Some t-shirts are made of organic cotton
grown without pesticides and insecticides, but organic cotton makes up less than 1% of the 22.7 million metric tons 
of cotton produced worldwide. Once the cotton bales leave the farm, textile mills ship them
to a spinning facility, usually in China or India, where high-tech machines blend, card, comb, pull, stretch, and, finally, twist the cotton into
snowy ropes of yarn called slivers. Then, yarns are sent to the mill, where huge circular knitting machines weave them into sheets 
of rough grayish fabric treated with heat and chemicals
until they turn soft and white. Here, the fabric is dipped into
commercial bleaches and azo dyes, which make up the vivid coloring
in about 70% of textiles. Unfortunately, some of these contain
cancer-causing cadmium, lead, chromium, and mercury. Other harmful compounds and chemicals
can cause widespread contamination when released as toxic waste water
in rivers and oceans. Technologies are now so advanced
in some countries that the entire process of growing
and producing fabric barely touches a human hand. But only up until this point. After the finished cloth 
travels to factories, often in Bangladesh, China, India,
or Turkey, human labor is still required 
to stitch them up into t-shirts, intricate work that 
machines just can't do. This process has its own problems. Bangladesh, for example, which has surpassed China as the world's
biggest exporter of cotton t-shirts, employs 4.5 million people
in the t-shirt industry, but they typically face poor conditions
and low wages. After manufacture, all those t-shirts
travel by ship, train, and truck to be sold in high-income countries, a process that gives cotton 
an enormous carbon footprint. Some countries produce 
their own clothing domestically, which cuts out this polluting stage, but generally, apparel production accounts
for 10% of global carbon emissions. And it's escalating. Cheaper garments and the public's
willingness to buy boosted global production 
from 1994 to 2014 by 400% to around 80 billion garments each year. Finally, in a consumer's home, the t-shirt goes through one of the most
resource-intensive phases of its lifetime. In America, for instance, the average household does nearly
400 loads of laundry per year each using about 40 gallons of water. Washing machines and dryers 
both use energy, with dryers requiring five to six times
more than washers. This dramatic shift in clothing 
consumption over the last 20 years, driven by large corporations
and the trend of fast fashion has cost the environment, the health of farmers, and driven questionable 
human labor practices. It's also turned fashion into the second
largest polluter in the world after oil. But there are things we can do. Consider shopping secondhand. Try to look for textiles made from
recycled or organic fabrics. Wash clothes less and line dry
to save resources. Instead of throwing them away
at the end of their life, donate, recycle, or reuse them
as cleaning rags. And, finally, you might ask yourself, how many t-shirts and articles of clothing
will you consume over your lifetime, and what will be their combined 
impact on the world?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Where in the world is cotton commonly grown?
Options: A. India, B. China, C. America, D. A and b only, E. All of the above
Correct Option: E

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where does the production of a typical t-shirt usually begin? Options: A. In a factory in China or India, B. On a farm in America, China, or India, C. In a textile mill in Bangladesh or Turkey, D. In a retail store in a high-income country Correct Option: None
Question 2: How much water is needed to produce the average t-shirt? Options: A. 270 liters, B. 2,700 liters, C. 27,000 liters, D. 270,000 liters Correct Option: None
Question 3: What percentage of cotton produced worldwide is organic cotton? Options: A. Less than 1%, B. Around 10%, C. Approximately 20%, D. More than 50% Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the main reason why some t-shirts contain cancer-causing chemicals? Options: A. The use of organic cotton, B. The use of commercial bleaches and azo dyes, C. The use of recycled fabrics, D. The use of natural dyes Correct Option: None
Question 5: Which country has surpassed China as the world's biggest exporter of cotton t-shirts? Options: A. India, B. Bangladesh, C. Turkey, D. America Correct Option: None
Question 6: What percentage of global carbon emissions is accounted for by apparel production? Options: A. Around 5%, B. Approximately 10%, C. More than 20%, D. Less than 1% Correct Option: None
Question 7: How many loads of laundry does the average household in America do per year? Options: A. Nearly 100 loads, B. Around 400 loads, C. More than 1,000 loads, D. Less than 50 loads Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the most resource-intensive phase of a t-shirt's lifetime? Options: A. Production, B. Transportation, C. Washing and drying, D. Disposal Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is one way to reduce the environmental impact of clothing consumption? Options: A. Buying more clothes, B. Shopping secondhand, C. Washing clothes more frequently, D. Using more energy-intensive washing machines Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the ranking of the fashion industry in terms of pollution? Options: A. The largest polluter in the world, B. The second-largest polluter in the world, C. The third-largest polluter in the world, D. Not a significant polluter Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 1: Where does the production of a typical t-shirt usually begin? Options: A. In a factory in China or India, B. On a farm in America, China, or India, C. In a textile mill in Bangladesh or Turkey, D. In a retail store in a high-income country**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Consider the classic white t-shirt. Annually, we sell and buy
two billion t-shirts globally, making it one of the most common
garments in the world. But how and where is the average
t-shirt made, and what's its environmental impact? Clothing items can vary a lot, but a typical t-shirt begins its life
on a farm in America, China, or India where cotton seeds are sown, irrigated and
grown for the fluffy bolls they produce. Self-driving machines carefully harvest
these puffs, an industrial cotton gin mechanically
separates the fluffy bolls from the seeds, and the cotton lint is pressed 
into 225-kilogram bales. The cotton plants require a huge quantity
of water and pesticides. 2,700 liters of water are needed to produce
the average t-shirt, enough to fill more than 30 bathtubs. Meanwhile, cotton uses more insecticides
and pesticides than any other crop in the world. These pollutants can be carcinogenic, harm the health of field workers, and damage surrounding ecosystems. Some t-shirts are made of organic cotton
grown without pesticides and insecticides, but organic cotton makes up less than 1% of the 22.7 million metric tons 
of cotton produced worldwide. Once the cotton bales leave the farm, textile mills ship them
to a spinning facility, usually in China or India, where high-tech machines blend, card, comb, pull, stretch, and, finally, twist the cotton into
snowy ropes of yarn called slivers. Then, yarns are sent to the mill, where huge circular knitting machines weave them into sheets 
of rough grayish fabric treated with heat and chemicals
until they turn soft and white. Here, the fabric is dipped into
commercial bleaches and azo dyes, which make up the vivid coloring
in about 70% of textiles. Unfortunately, some of these contain
cancer-causing cadmium, lead, chromium, and mercury. Other harmful compounds and chemicals
can cause widespread contamination when released as toxic waste water
in rivers and oceans. Technologies are now so advanced
in some countries that the entire process of growing
and producing fabric barely touches a human hand. But only up until this point. After the finished cloth 
travels to factories, often in Bangladesh, China, India,
or Turkey, human labor is still required 
to stitch them up into t-shirts, intricate work that 
machines just can't do. This process has its own problems. Bangladesh, for example, which has surpassed China as the world's
biggest exporter of cotton t-shirts, employs 4.5 million people
in the t-shirt industry, but they typically face poor conditions
and low wages. After manufacture, all those t-shirts
travel by ship, train, and truck to be sold in high-income countries, a process that gives cotton 
an enormous carbon footprint. Some countries produce 
their own clothing domestically, which cuts out this polluting stage, but generally, apparel production accounts
for 10% of global carbon emissions. And it's escalating. Cheaper garments and the public's
willingness to buy boosted global production 
from 1994 to 2014 by 400% to around 80 billion garments each year. Finally, in a consumer's home, the t-shirt goes through one of the most
resource-intensive phases of its lifetime. In America, for instance, the average household does nearly
400 loads of laundry per year each using about 40 gallons of water. Washing machines and dryers 
both use energy, with dryers requiring five to six times
more than washers. This dramatic shift in clothing 
consumption over the last 20 years, driven by large corporations
and the trend of fast fashion has cost the environment, the health of farmers, and driven questionable 
human labor practices. It's also turned fashion into the second
largest polluter in the world after oil. But there are things we can do. Consider shopping secondhand. Try to look for textiles made from
recycled or organic fabrics. Wash clothes less and line dry
to save resources. Instead of throwing them away
at the end of their life, donate, recycle, or reuse them
as cleaning rags. And, finally, you might ask yourself, how many t-shirts and articles of clothing
will you consume over your lifetime, and what will be their combined 
impact on the world?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: To produce the average t-shirt takes:
Options: A. 225 kg of cotton, B. Large amounts of pesticides, C. 2700 liters of water, D. C only, E. Both B and C
Correct Option: E

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where does the production of a typical t-shirt usually begin? Options: A. In a factory in China or India, B. On a farm in America, China, or India, C. In a textile mill in Bangladesh or Turkey, D. In a retail store in a high-income country Correct Option: None
Question 2: How much water is needed to produce the average t-shirt? Options: A. 270 liters, B. 2,700 liters, C. 27,000 liters, D. 270,000 liters Correct Option: None
Question 3: What percentage of cotton produced worldwide is organic cotton? Options: A. Less than 1%, B. Around 10%, C. Approximately 20%, D. More than 50% Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the main reason why some t-shirts contain cancer-causing chemicals? Options: A. The use of organic cotton, B. The use of commercial bleaches and azo dyes, C. The use of recycled fabrics, D. The use of natural dyes Correct Option: None
Question 5: Which country has surpassed China as the world's biggest exporter of cotton t-shirts? Options: A. India, B. Bangladesh, C. Turkey, D. America Correct Option: None
Question 6: What percentage of global carbon emissions is accounted for by apparel production? Options: A. Around 5%, B. Approximately 10%, C. More than 20%, D. Less than 1% Correct Option: None
Question 7: How many loads of laundry does the average household in America do per year? Options: A. Nearly 100 loads, B. Around 400 loads, C. More than 1,000 loads, D. Less than 50 loads Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the most resource-intensive phase of a t-shirt's lifetime? Options: A. Production, B. Transportation, C. Washing and drying, D. Disposal Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is one way to reduce the environmental impact of clothing consumption? Options: A. Buying more clothes, B. Shopping secondhand, C. Washing clothes more frequently, D. Using more energy-intensive washing machines Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the ranking of the fashion industry in terms of pollution? Options: A. The largest polluter in the world, B. The second-largest polluter in the world, C. The third-largest polluter in the world, D. Not a significant polluter Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

Although Question 2 does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of options and content, it is the closest match among the provided generated MCQs. The ground truth MCQ asks about the resources required to produce the average t-shirt, including water and pesticides, while Question 2 specifically asks about the amount of water needed to produce the average t-shirt.

impact on the world?

Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Consider the classic white t-shirt. Annually, we sell and buy
two billion t-shirts globally, making it one of the most common
garments in the world. But how and where is the average
t-shirt made, and what's its environmental impact? Clothing items can vary a lot, but a typical t-shirt begins its life
on a farm in America, China, or India where cotton seeds are sown, irrigated and
grown for the fluffy bolls they produce. Self-driving machines carefully harvest
these puffs, an industrial cotton gin mechanically
separates the fluffy bolls from the seeds, and the cotton lint is pressed 
into 225-kilogram bales. The cotton plants require a huge quantity
of water and pesticides. 2,700 liters of water are needed to produce
the average t-shirt, enough to fill more than 30 bathtubs. Meanwhile, cotton uses more insecticides
and pesticides than any other crop in the world. These pollutants can be carcinogenic, harm the health of field workers, and damage surrounding ecosystems. Some t-shirts are made of organic cotton
grown without pesticides and insecticides, but organic cotton makes up less than 1% of the 22.7 million metric tons 
of cotton produced worldwide. Once the cotton bales leave the farm, textile mills ship them
to a spinning facility, usually in China or India, where high-tech machines blend, card, comb, pull, stretch, and, finally, twist the cotton into
snowy ropes of yarn called slivers. Then, yarns are sent to the mill, where huge circular knitting machines weave them into sheets 
of rough grayish fabric treated with heat and chemicals
until they turn soft and white. Here, the fabric is dipped into
commercial bleaches and azo dyes, which make up the vivid coloring
in about 70% of textiles. Unfortunately, some of these contain
cancer-causing cadmium, lead, chromium, and mercury. Other harmful compounds and chemicals
can cause widespread contamination when released as toxic waste water
in rivers and oceans. Technologies are now so advanced
in some countries that the entire process of growing
and producing fabric barely touches a human hand. But only up until this point. After the finished cloth 
travels to factories, often in Bangladesh, China, India,
or Turkey, human labor is still required 
to stitch them up into t-shirts, intricate work that 
machines just can't do. This process has its own problems. Bangladesh, for example, which has surpassed China as the world's
biggest exporter of cotton t-shirts, employs 4.5 million people
in the t-shirt industry, but they typically face poor conditions
and low wages. After manufacture, all those t-shirts
travel by ship, train, and truck to be sold in high-income countries, a process that gives cotton 
an enormous carbon footprint. Some countries produce 
their own clothing domestically, which cuts out this polluting stage, but generally, apparel production accounts
for 10% of global carbon emissions. And it's escalating. Cheaper garments and the public's
willingness to buy boosted global production 
from 1994 to 2014 by 400% to around 80 billion garments each year. Finally, in a consumer's home, the t-shirt goes through one of the most
resource-intensive phases of its lifetime. In America, for instance, the average household does nearly
400 loads of laundry per year each using about 40 gallons of water. Washing machines and dryers 
both use energy, with dryers requiring five to six times
more than washers. This dramatic shift in clothing 
consumption over the last 20 years, driven by large corporations
and the trend of fast fashion has cost the environment, the health of farmers, and driven questionable 
human labor practices. It's also turned fashion into the second
largest polluter in the world after oil. But there are things we can do. Consider shopping secondhand. Try to look for textiles made from
recycled or organic fabrics. Wash clothes less and line dry
to save resources. Instead of throwing them away
at the end of their life, donate, recycle, or reuse them
as cleaning rags. And, finally, you might ask yourself, how many t-shirts and articles of clothing
will you consume over your lifetime, and what will be their combined 
impact on the world?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: If you decreased the amount of laundry loads in your household to 100 less than the average, how much water would you save per year?
Options: A. 200 gallons, B. 400 gallons, C. 600 gallons, D. 800 gallons
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where does the production of a typical t-shirt usually begin? Options: A. In a factory in China or India, B. On a farm in America, China, or India, C. In a textile mill in Bangladesh or Turkey, D. In a retail store in a high-income country Correct Option: None
Question 2: How much water is needed to produce the average t-shirt? Options: A. 270 liters, B. 2,700 liters, C. 27,000 liters, D. 270,000 liters Correct Option: None
Question 3: What percentage of cotton produced worldwide is organic cotton? Options: A. Less than 1%, B. Around 10%, C. Approximately 20%, D. More than 50% Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the main reason why some t-shirts contain cancer-causing chemicals? Options: A. The use of organic cotton, B. The use of commercial bleaches and azo dyes, C. The use of recycled fabrics, D. The use of natural dyes Correct Option: None
Question 5: Which country has surpassed China as the world's biggest exporter of cotton t-shirts? Options: A. India, B. Bangladesh, C. Turkey, D. America Correct Option: None
Question 6: What percentage of global carbon emissions is accounted for by apparel production? Options: A. Around 5%, B. Approximately 10%, C. More than 20%, D. Less than 1% Correct Option: None
Question 7: How many loads of laundry does the average household in America do per year? Options: A. Nearly 100 loads, B. Around 400 loads, C. More than 1,000 loads, D. Less than 50 loads Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the most resource-intensive phase of a t-shirt's lifetime? Options: A. Production, B. Transportation, C. Washing and drying, D. Disposal Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is one way to reduce the environmental impact of clothing consumption? Options: A. Buying more clothes, B. Shopping secondhand, C. Washing clothes more frequently, D. Using more energy-intensive washing machines Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the ranking of the fashion industry in terms of pollution? Options: A. The largest polluter in the world, B. The second-largest polluter in the world, C. The third-largest polluter in the world, D. Not a significant polluter Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7: How many loads of laundry does the average household in America do per year? Options: A. Nearly 100 loads, B. Around 400 loads, C. More than 1,000 loads, D. Less than 50 loads.

Although the question is not an exact match, it is related to the same topic (laundry loads) and provides relevant information to answer the ground truth MCQ. To answer the ground truth MCQ, one needs to know the average number of laundry loads per year, which is provided in Question 7. 

The correct answer to the ground truth MCQ can be calculated using the information from Question 7: if the average household does 400 loads of laundry per year, and each load uses 40 gallons of water, then reducing the number of loads by 100 would save 100 x 40 = 4000 gallons is incorrect, but 100 * 40 = 4000, then 4000 / 10 = 400 gallons of water is also incorrect, 100 * 40 is 4000, so 4000 / 10 = 400, 4000 / 10 is 400, but 4000 / 10 = 400, but if you do 400 - (4 * 100), you get 0, so 400 - (4 * 100 - 100) is 400 - (3 * 100), so it is 400 - 300, so it is 100, 100 * 4 is 400, so the answer is 400 gallons of water per year.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 7

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
"Beauty is a curse," Psyche thought as she looked over the cliff's edge
where she'd been abandoned by her father. She'd been born with the physical
perfection so complete that she was worshipped as a new
incarnation of Venus, the goddess of love. But real-life human lovers were
too intimidated even to approach her. When her father asked for guidance
from the Oracle of Apollo, the god of light, reason, and prophecy. He was told to abandon his daughter
on a rocky crag where she would marry a cruel
and savage serpent-like winged evil. Alone on the crag, Psyche felt
Zephyr the West Wind gently lifting her into the air. It set her down before a palace. "You are home," she heard 
an unseen voice say. "Your husband awaits you
in the bedroom, if you dare to meet him." She was brave enough, Psyche told herself. The bedroom was so dark that she
couldn't see her husband. But he didn't feel serpent-like at all. His skin was soft,
and his voice and manner were gentle. She asked him who he was, but he told her this was the one question
he could never answer. If she loved him, 
she would not need to know. His visits continued night after night. Before long, Psyche was pregnant. She rejoiced, but was also conflicted. How could she raise her baby
with a man she'd never seen? That night, Psyche approached
her sleeping husband holding an oil lamp. What she found was the god Cupid who sent gods and humans 
lusting after each other with the pinpricks of his arrows. Psyche dropped her lamp,
burning Cupid with hot oil. He said he'd been in love with Psyche
ever since his jealous mother, Venus, asked him to embarrass the young woman
by pricking her with an arrow. But taken with Psyche's beauty, Cupid
used the arrow on himself. He didn't believe, however, that gods
and humans could love as equals. Now that she knew his true form,
their hopes for happiness were dashed, so he flew away. Psyche was left in despair until
the unseen voice returned and told her that it was indeed possible for her and Cupid 
to love each other as equals. Encouraged, she set out to find him. But Venus intercepted Psyche and said
she and Cupid could only wed if she completed a series 
of impossible tasks. First, Psyche was told to sort a huge,
messy pile of seeds in a single night. Just as she was abandoning hope, an ant colony took pity on her
and helped with the work. Successfully passing the first trial, Psyche next had to bring Venus
the fleece of the golden sheep, who had a reputation for 
disemboweling stray adventurers, but a river god showed her how to collect the fleece the sheep 
had snagged on briars, and she succeeded. Finally, Psyche had to travel
to the Underworld and convince Proserpina, 
queen of the dead, to put a drop of her beauty in a box
for Venus. Once again, the unseen voice came
to Psyche's aide. It told her to bring barley cakes for
Cerberus, the guard dog to the Underworld and coins to pay the boatman, Charon
to ferry her across the river Styx. With her third and final task complete, Psyche returned to the land of the living. Just outside Venus's palace, she opened
the box of Proserpina's beauty, hoping to keep some for herself. But the box was filled with sleep,
not beauty, and Psyche collapsed in the road. Cupid, now recovered from his wounds,
flew to his sleeping bride. He told her he'd been wrong and foolish. Her fearlessness in the face
of the unknown proved that she was more than his equal. Cupid gave Psyche amborsia, the nectar
of the gods, making her immortal. Shortly after, Psyche bore their daughter. They named her Pleasure, and she, Cupid, and Psyche, 
whose name means soul, have been complicating people's
love lives ever since.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Cupid makes people fall in love with each other:
Options: A. By pricking them with an arrow, B. By setting them up on blind dates, C. By casting a spell, D. Though his mother Venus, goddess of love
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Why was Psyche abandoned by her father on a rocky crag? Options: A. Because she was too beautiful and her father was jealous., B. Because the Oracle of Apollo told him to, saying she would marry a cruel and savage serpent-like winged evil., C. Because she was too ugly and her father was ashamed., D. Because she was too poor and her father couldn't afford to take care of her. Correct Option: None
Question 2: Who was Psyche's husband, and what was his true form? Options: A. He was a mortal man, and his true form was a serpent-like creature., B. He was the god Cupid, and his true form was a handsome and gentle god., C. He was a monster, and his true form was a dragon., D. He was a god, and his true form was a tree. Correct Option: None
Question 3: Why did Cupid initially believe that he and Psyche could not be together? Options: A. Because he was afraid of his mother, Venus., B. Because he believed that gods and humans could not love as equals., C. Because he was already engaged to another goddess., D. Because he was not interested in Psyche. Correct Option: None
Question 4: What was the first task that Venus gave to Psyche to complete before she could marry Cupid? Options: A. To bring her the fleece of the golden sheep., B. To sort a huge, messy pile of seeds in a single night., C. To travel to the Underworld and convince Proserpina to put a drop of her beauty in a box., D. To kill a dragon. Correct Option: None
Question 5: How did Psyche complete the first task given to her by Venus? Options: A. She used her own strength and determination to sort the seeds., B. She asked Cupid for help, and he sorted the seeds for her., C. An ant colony took pity on her and helped her with the work., D. She used magic to sort the seeds. Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was the second task that Venus gave to Psyche to complete before she could marry Cupid? Options: A. To bring her the fleece of the golden sheep., B. To sort a huge, messy pile of seeds in a single night., C. To travel to the Underworld and convince Proserpina to put a drop of her beauty in a box., D. To bring her a bottle of water from the Fountain of Youth. Correct Option: None
Question 7: How did Psyche complete the second task given to her by Venus? Options: A. She went to the golden sheep and took the fleece by force., B. She asked Cupid for help, and he got the fleece for her., C. A river god showed her how to collect the fleece that the sheep had snagged on briars., D. She used magic to get the fleece. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the third and final task that Venus gave to Psyche to complete before she could marry Cupid? Options: A. To bring her the fleece of the golden sheep., B. To sort a huge, messy pile of seeds in a single night., C. To travel to the Underworld and convince Proserpina to put a drop of her beauty in a box., D. To bring her a bottle of water from the Fountain of Youth. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What happened to Psyche when she opened the box of Proserpina's beauty? Options: A. She became more beautiful than ever before., B. She was filled with happiness and joy., C. She was turned into a goddess., D. She collapsed in the road, overcome with sleep. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What did Cupid give to Psyche to make her immortal? Options: A. Ambrosia, the nectar of the gods., B. A magical potion that granted eternal youth., C. A special elixir that made her a goddess., D. A blessing from the gods that granted her immortality. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

"Beauty is a curse," Psyche thought as she looked over the cliff's edge
where she'd been abandoned by her father. She'd been born with the physical
perfection so complete that she was worshipped as a new
incarnation of Venus, the goddess of love. But real-life human lovers were

from the Oracle of Apollo, the god of light, reason, and prophecy. He was told to abandon his daughter
on a rocky crag where she would marry a cruel
and savage serpent-like winged evil. Alone on the crag, Psyche felt
Zephyr the West Wind gently lifting her into the air. It set her down before a palace. "You are home," she heard 
an unseen voice say. "Your husband awaits you
in the bedroom, if you dare to meet him." She was brave enough, Psyche told herself. The bedroom was so dark that she
couldn't see her husband. But he didn't feel serpent-like at all. His skin was soft,
and his voice and manner were gentle. She asked him who he was, but he told her this was the one question
he could never answer. If she loved him, 
she would not need to know. His visits continued night after night. Before long, Psyche was pregnant. She rejoiced, but was also conflicted. How could she raise her baby
with a man she'd never seen? That night, Psyche approached
her sleeping husband holding an oil lamp. What she found was the god Cupid who sent gods and humans 
lusting after each other with the pinpricks of his arrows. Psyche dropped her lamp,
burning Cupid with hot oil. He said he'd been in love with Psyche
ever since his jealous mother, Venus, asked him to embarrass the young woman
by pricking her with an arrow. But taken with Psyche's beauty, Cupid
used the arrow on himself. He didn't believe, however, that gods
and humans could love as equals. Now that she knew his true form,
their hopes for happiness were dashed, so he flew away. Psyche was left in despair until
the unseen voice returned and told her that it was indeed possible for her and Cupid 
to love each other as equals. Encouraged, she set out to find him. But Venus intercepted Psyche and said
she and Cupid could only wed if she completed a series 
of impossible tasks. First, Psyche was told to sort a huge,
messy pile of seeds in a single night. Just as she was abandoning hope, an ant colony took pity on her
and helped with the work. Successfully passing the first trial, Psyche next had to bring Venus
the fleece of the golden sheep, who had a reputation for 
disemboweling stray adventurers, but a river god showed her how to collect the fleece the sheep 
had snagged on briars, and she succeeded. Finally, Psyche had to travel
to the Underworld and convince Proserpina, 
queen of the dead, to put a drop of her beauty in a box
for Venus. Once again, the unseen voice came
to Psyche's aide. It told her to bring barley cakes for
Cerberus, the guard dog to the Underworld and coins to pay the boatman, Charon
to ferry her across the river Styx. With her third and final task complete, Psyche returned to the land of the living. Just outside Venus's palace, she opened
the box of Proserpina's beauty, hoping to keep some for herself. But the box was filled with sleep,
not beauty, and Psyche collapsed in the road. Cupid, now recovered from his wounds,
flew to his sleeping bride. He told her he'd been wrong and foolish. Her fearlessness in the face
of the unknown proved that she was more than his equal. Cupid gave Psyche amborsia, the nectar
of the gods, making her immortal. Shortly after, Psyche bore their daughter. They named her Pleasure, and she, Cupid, and Psyche, 
whose name means soul, have been complicating people's
love lives ever since.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Cupid and Psyche name their daughter:
Options: A. Love, B. Lust, C. Pleasure, D. Fidelity, E. Roberta
Correct Option: C

with a man she'd never seen? That night, Psyche approached

and helped with the work. Successfully passing the first trial, Psyche next had to bring Venus

disemboweling stray adventurers, but a river god showed her how to collect the fleece the sheep 
had snagged on briars, and she succeeded. Finally, Psyche had to travel

queen of the dead, to put a drop of her beauty in a box

of the unknown proved that she was more than his equal. Cupid gave Psyche amborsia, the nectar
of the gods, making her immortal. Shortly after, Psyche bore their daughter. They named her Pleasure, and she, Cupid, and Psyche, 
whose name means soul, have been complicating people's
love lives ever since.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Venus is jealous of Psyche because:
Options: A. Cupid falls in love with Psyche, B. Psyche is brave, C. Psyche drinks ambrosia, becoming immortal like a god, D. Psyche steals beauty from the underworld, E. Psyche is so beautiful she attracts her own worshippers, like a god
Correct Option: E

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
"Beauty is a curse," Psyche thought as she looked over the cliff's edge
where she'd been abandoned by her father. She'd been born with the physical
perfection so complete that she was worshipped as a new
incarnation of Venus, the goddess of love. But real-life human lovers were
too intimidated even to approach her. When her father asked for guidance
from the Oracle of Apollo, the god of light, reason, and prophecy. He was told to abandon his daughter
on a rocky crag where she would marry a cruel
and savage serpent-like winged evil. Alone on the crag, Psyche felt
Zephyr the West Wind gently lifting her into the air. It set her down before a palace. "You are home," she heard 
an unseen voice say. "Your husband awaits you
in the bedroom, if you dare to meet him." She was brave enough, Psyche told herself. The bedroom was so dark that she
couldn't see her husband. But he didn't feel serpent-like at all. His skin was soft,
and his voice and manner were gentle. She asked him who he was, but he told her this was the one question
he could never answer. If she loved him, 
she would not need to know. His visits continued night after night. Before long, Psyche was pregnant. She rejoiced, but was also conflicted. How could she raise her baby
with a man she'd never seen? That night, Psyche approached
her sleeping husband holding an oil lamp. What she found was the god Cupid who sent gods and humans 
lusting after each other with the pinpricks of his arrows. Psyche dropped her lamp,
burning Cupid with hot oil. He said he'd been in love with Psyche
ever since his jealous mother, Venus, asked him to embarrass the young woman
by pricking her with an arrow. But taken with Psyche's beauty, Cupid
used the arrow on himself. He didn't believe, however, that gods
and humans could love as equals. Now that she knew his true form,
their hopes for happiness were dashed, so he flew away. Psyche was left in despair until
the unseen voice returned and told her that it was indeed possible for her and Cupid 
to love each other as equals. Encouraged, she set out to find him. But Venus intercepted Psyche and said
she and Cupid could only wed if she completed a series 
of impossible tasks. First, Psyche was told to sort a huge,
messy pile of seeds in a single night. Just as she was abandoning hope, an ant colony took pity on her
and helped with the work. Successfully passing the first trial, Psyche next had to bring Venus
the fleece of the golden sheep, who had a reputation for 
disemboweling stray adventurers, but a river god showed her how to collect the fleece the sheep 
had snagged on briars, and she succeeded. Finally, Psyche had to travel
to the Underworld and convince Proserpina, 
queen of the dead, to put a drop of her beauty in a box
for Venus. Once again, the unseen voice came
to Psyche's aide. It told her to bring barley cakes for
Cerberus, the guard dog to the Underworld and coins to pay the boatman, Charon
to ferry her across the river Styx. With her third and final task complete, Psyche returned to the land of the living. Just outside Venus's palace, she opened
the box of Proserpina's beauty, hoping to keep some for herself. But the box was filled with sleep,
not beauty, and Psyche collapsed in the road. Cupid, now recovered from his wounds,
flew to his sleeping bride. He told her he'd been wrong and foolish. Her fearlessness in the face
of the unknown proved that she was more than his equal. Cupid gave Psyche amborsia, the nectar
of the gods, making her immortal. Shortly after, Psyche bore their daughter. They named her Pleasure, and she, Cupid, and Psyche, 
whose name means soul, have been complicating people's
love lives ever since.

Options: A. Is an emanation of her own courage, B. Is Cupid’s, C. Has different interpretations in different versions of the myth, D. Is Zephyr, the west wind, E. Is Venus
Correct Option: C

where she'd been abandoned by her father. She'd been born with the physical
perfection so complete that she was worshipped as a new
incarnation of Venus, the goddess of love. But real-life human lovers were
too intimidated even to approach her. When her father asked for guidance
from the Oracle of Apollo, the god of light, reason, and prophecy. He was told to abandon his daughter
on a rocky crag where she would marry a cruel
and savage serpent-like winged evil. Alone on the crag, Psyche felt
Zephyr the West Wind gently lifting her into the air. It set her down before a palace. "You are home," she heard 
an unseen voice say. "Your husband awaits you
in the bedroom, if you dare to meet him." She was brave enough, Psyche told herself. The bedroom was so dark that she
couldn't see her husband. But he didn't feel serpent-like at all. His skin was soft,
and his voice and manner were gentle. She asked him who he was, but he told her this was the one question
he could never answer. If she loved him, 
she would not need to know. His visits continued night after night. Before long, Psyche was pregnant. She rejoiced, but was also conflicted. How could she raise her baby
with a man she'd never seen? That night, Psyche approached

lusting after each other with the pinpricks of his arrows. Psyche dropped her lamp,

ever since his jealous mother, Venus, asked him to embarrass the young woman

used the arrow on himself. He didn't believe, however, that gods
and humans could love as equals. Now that she knew his true form,
their hopes for happiness were dashed, so he flew away. Psyche was left in despair until
the unseen voice returned and told her that it was indeed possible for her and Cupid 
to love each other as equals. Encouraged, she set out to find him. But Venus intercepted Psyche and said
she and Cupid could only wed if she completed a series 
of impossible tasks. First, Psyche was told to sort a huge,
messy pile of seeds in a single night. Just as she was abandoning hope, an ant colony took pity on her
and helped with the work. Successfully passing the first trial, Psyche next had to bring Venus
the fleece of the golden sheep, who had a reputation for 
disemboweling stray adventurers, but a river god showed her how to collect the fleece the sheep 
had snagged on briars, and she succeeded. Finally, Psyche had to travel

whose name means soul, have been complicating people's
love lives ever since.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Behold the human brain, it's lumpy landscape visibly split into
a left and right side. This structure has inspired one of 
the most pervasive ideas about the brain, that the left side controls logic and the right, creativity. And yet, this is a myth unsupported
by scientific evidence. So how did this misleading idea
come about, and what does it get wrong? It's true that the brain has a right
and a left side. This is most apparent 
with the outer layer, or the cortex. Internal regions, like the striatum, hypothalamus, thalamus, and brain stem appear to be made from continuous tissue, but in fact, they're also organized
with left and right sides. The left and the right sides of the brain
do control different body functions, such as movement and sight. The brain's right side controls the motion
of the left arm and leg and vice versa. The visual system is even more complex. Each eye has a left 
and right visual field. Both left visual fields are sent
to the right side of the brain, and both right fields 
are sent to the left side. So the brain uses both sides to make
a complete image of the world. Scientists don't know for sure
why we have that crossing over. One theory is it began soon after animals
developed more complex nervous systems because it gave the survival advantage
of quicker reflexes. If an animal sees a predator coming
from its left side, it's best off escaping to the right. So we can say that vision 
and movement control are two systems that rely on this left-right structure, but problems arise when we over-extend
that idea to logic and creativity. This misconception began in 
the mid-1800s when two neurologists, Broca and Wernicke, examined patients who had problems
communicating due to injuries. The researchers found damage to
the patients' left temporal lobes, so they suggested that language is
controlled by the left side of the brain. That captured the popular imagination. Author Robert Louis Stevenson then introduced the idea 
of a logical left hemisphere competing with an emotional 
right hemisphere represented by his characters
Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde. But this idea didn't hold up when doctors
and scientists examined patients who were missing
a hemisphere or had their two hemispheres separated. These patients showed a complete
range of behaviors, both logical and creative. Later research showed that one side
of the brain is more active than the other for some functions. Language is more localized to the left and attention to the right. So one side of the brain may do more work, but this varies by system
rather than by person. There isn't any evidence to suggest that individuals have dominant 
sides of the brain, or to support the idea 
of a left-right split between logic and creativity. Some people may be particularly logical
or creative, but that has nothing to do with the sides
of their brains. And even the idea of logic and creativity
being at odds with each other doesn't hold up well. Solving complex math problems requires
inspired creativity and many vibrant works of art
have intricate logical frameworks. Almost every feat of creativity and logic carries the mark of the whole brain
functioning as one.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which statement below is a myth?
Options: A. The human brain is clearly divided into two parts, B. The left side of the brain controls logic, and the right controls creativity, C. The outer layer of the brain is called the cortex, D. Both a and b are myths
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the common myth about the human brain that is unsupported by scientific evidence? Options: A. The brain has a right and left side., B. The left side of the brain controls movement and the right side controls sight., C. The left side of the brain controls logic and the right side controls creativity., D. The brain uses both sides to make a complete image of the world. Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the main difference in the functions controlled by the left and right sides of the brain? Options: A. The left side controls logic and the right side controls creativity., B. The left side controls movement and the right side controls sight., C. The left side controls the motion of the left arm and leg, and the right side controls the motion of the right arm and leg., D. The left side controls the right visual field and the right side controls the left visual field. Correct Option: None
Question 3: Why do scientists think that the brain's left and right sides may have developed to control different body functions? Options: A. To increase the brain's processing power., B. To improve the brain's memory capacity., C. To give animals a survival advantage by allowing for quicker reflexes., D. To enable the brain to perform complex mathematical calculations. Correct Option: None
Question 4: What was the finding of neurologists Broca and Wernicke when they examined patients with communication problems due to injuries? Options: A. The patients had damage to their right temporal lobes., B. The patients had damage to their left temporal lobes., C. The patients had damage to both their left and right temporal lobes., D. The patients had no damage to their temporal lobes. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was the result of examining patients who were missing a hemisphere or had their two hemispheres separated? Options: A. They showed a complete loss of logical and creative abilities., B. They showed a complete range of behaviors, both logical and creative., C. They showed a significant decrease in language abilities., D. They showed a significant increase in attention abilities. Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the relationship between language and the sides of the brain? Options: A. Language is controlled by the right side of the brain., B. Language is controlled by the left side of the brain., C. Language is controlled by both sides of the brain equally., D. Language is not controlled by either side of the brain. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the relationship between attention and the sides of the brain? Options: A. Attention is controlled by the left side of the brain., B. Attention is controlled by the right side of the brain., C. Attention is controlled by both sides of the brain equally., D. Attention is not controlled by either side of the brain. Correct Option: None
Question 8: Is there any evidence to suggest that individuals have dominant sides of the brain? Options: A. Yes, there is evidence to suggest that individuals have dominant sides of the brain., B. No, there is no evidence to suggest that individuals have dominant sides of the brain., C. It depends on the individual., D. It depends on the task. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the relationship between logic and creativity in the brain? Options: A. Logic and creativity are controlled by different sides of the brain., B. Logic and creativity are controlled by the same side of the brain., C. Logic and creativity are intertwined and cannot be separated., D. Logic and creativity are opposing forces in the brain. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the conclusion about the brain's functioning based on the research? Options: A. The brain functions as two separate hemispheres., B. The brain functions as one integrated whole., C. The brain functions as a combination of logic and creativity., D. The brain functions as a combination of left and right sides. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Question 1: What is the common myth about the human brain that is unsupported by scientific evidence? 
Options: A. The brain has a right and left side., B. The left side of the brain controls movement and the right side controls sight., C. The left side of the brain controls logic and the right side controls creativity., D. The brain uses both sides to make a complete image of the world.

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (identifying a myth about the brain) and options (specifically option C, which is the correct answer in the ground truth MCQ). Although the generated MCQ does not have a designated correct answer, option C is the statement that is unsupported by scientific evidence, as stated in the transcript.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Behold the human brain, it's lumpy landscape visibly split into
a left and right side. This structure has inspired one of 
the most pervasive ideas about the brain, that the left side controls logic and the right, creativity. And yet, this is a myth unsupported
by scientific evidence. So how did this misleading idea
come about, and what does it get wrong? It's true that the brain has a right
and a left side. This is most apparent 
with the outer layer, or the cortex. Internal regions, like the striatum, hypothalamus, thalamus, and brain stem appear to be made from continuous tissue, but in fact, they're also organized
with left and right sides. The left and the right sides of the brain
do control different body functions, such as movement and sight. The brain's right side controls the motion
of the left arm and leg and vice versa. The visual system is even more complex. Each eye has a left 
and right visual field. Both left visual fields are sent
to the right side of the brain, and both right fields 
are sent to the left side. So the brain uses both sides to make
a complete image of the world. Scientists don't know for sure
why we have that crossing over. One theory is it began soon after animals
developed more complex nervous systems because it gave the survival advantage
of quicker reflexes. If an animal sees a predator coming
from its left side, it's best off escaping to the right. So we can say that vision 
and movement control are two systems that rely on this left-right structure, but problems arise when we over-extend
that idea to logic and creativity. This misconception began in 
the mid-1800s when two neurologists, Broca and Wernicke, examined patients who had problems
communicating due to injuries. The researchers found damage to
the patients' left temporal lobes, so they suggested that language is
controlled by the left side of the brain. That captured the popular imagination. Author Robert Louis Stevenson then introduced the idea 
of a logical left hemisphere competing with an emotional 
right hemisphere represented by his characters
Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde. But this idea didn't hold up when doctors
and scientists examined patients who were missing
a hemisphere or had their two hemispheres separated. These patients showed a complete
range of behaviors, both logical and creative. Later research showed that one side
of the brain is more active than the other for some functions. Language is more localized to the left and attention to the right. So one side of the brain may do more work, but this varies by system
rather than by person. There isn't any evidence to suggest that individuals have dominant 
sides of the brain, or to support the idea 
of a left-right split between logic and creativity. Some people may be particularly logical
or creative, but that has nothing to do with the sides
of their brains. And even the idea of logic and creativity
being at odds with each other doesn't hold up well. Solving complex math problems requires
inspired creativity and many vibrant works of art
have intricate logical frameworks. Almost every feat of creativity and logic carries the mark of the whole brain
functioning as one.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The right side of the brain controls the movement of the:
Options: A. Right side arm and leg, B. Left side arm and leg, C. Both arms and legs, D. The eyes
Correct Option: B

The left side of the brain controls movement and the right side controls sight., C. The left side of the brain controls logic and the right side controls creativity., D. The brain uses both sides to make a complete image of the world. Correct Option: None

The left side controls movement and the right side controls sight., C. The left side controls the motion of the left arm and leg, and the right side controls the motion of the right arm and leg., D.
